I'm not a native speaker and learnt at school we should use "for instance", "for example", or for the abbreviation e.g., and in my case not to use the frenc ex. (which stands for «exemple»).
Then was it false, or was it a mistake on your part?

replies.bodyText: I think you can just use what you want. If it feels better for you, we can switch to E. g., but Ex. sounds as clear to me.
replies.author: Poolitzer

replies.bodyText: Ex. is wrong here semantically. It abbreviates "example". In this case, you have to go for either of @B0pol's suggestions (they're all basically the same). IMO using for example is the "simplest", and as we won't win a price for the most elegant resp. complex English sentence, we should go for accessibility. I have met dozens of non-native speakers who couldn't explain e.g., and many of them also have never heard for instance.

timeline.bodyText:
We are at the bottom of the template, and I disagree about "a clear and concise description" everywhere.
IMO, at least one paragraph should say:
Why you'd really want this feature? Explain how it will change your life and your NewPipe experience!
This was just an example, but the idea is to have one paragraph where people THINK about their request. Do they really WANT it, or it was just a thought they had but they don't really care about it.
And if they give good reasons why they really WANT it, we can understand better, and prioritize (dunno if it's how we say) these requests, or on the contrary, if they didn't give good reasons AND it seems like a niche request, maintaners / contributors will know there are more important things to fix / features to bring.

timeline.bodyText:
You didn't include a link to the contribution guidelines
Also, question to TeamNewpipe

Do not report crashes in the GitHub issue tracker. NewPipe has an automated crash report system that will ask you to send a report via e-mail when a crash occurs. This contains all the data we need for debugging, and allows you to even add a comment to it. You'll see exactly what is sent, the system is 100% transparent

You don't want people to just paste the crash report on GitHub because Sentry is better with automatization, but you are welcoming detailed report with steps to reproduce, further explaination… on GitHub, am I right?
Because if yes, this paragraph is not needed, by following the template people will give information. If no, we should write about that.

replies.bodyText:
You didn't include a link to the contribution guidelines

Not needed for a bug/feature report, not like they are actually contributing.
replies.author: Poolitzer

replies.bodyText:
Not needed for a bug/feature report, not like they are actually contributing.

The guidelines contain valuable information about reporting bugs or requesting features. Also, a simple link doesn't force people to follow it (although it would be better).

You don't want people to just paste the crash report on GitHub because Sentry is better with automatization, but you are welcoming detailed report with steps to reproduce, further explaination… on GitHub, am I right?

I think we need to make a poll with the regular contributors asking them about their usage of Sentry. To me it doesn't seem overly well used.
Depending on the result we have to define how bugs should be reported. Perhaps we can include a unique (enough) ID or something so that issues sent to Sentry can be found more easily on demand (i.e., the reporter can post that ID, and the devs can find the relevant Sentry entry by searching for it).
Not posting all the bug report information in public is also a good idea for privacy reasons. Why should we request anyone to post intimate details about their YouTube habits for bug reports?
We also intend to switch to an alternative/fork/successor, as Sentry has turned into a proprietary software lately*.
In any case, @TobiGr, it's up to you to decide how bugs should be reported. I just provided some ideas for improvements.
*(Damn all those generous CLAs from companies! They really make sense for non-profit projects only if they're restricted to stuff relevant for copyright cases in courts (i.e., they need to be worded in a way so the license can't be changed but the company has the copyright "officially" so they can actually sue others), and non-profits don't misuse them for turning software proprietary...)

The problem is that Sentry is too messy and searching logs in Sentry is quite difficult. We might also consider to not accept bugs from older versions.
